title-group.article-title: Mobilization of storage lipid reserve and expression analysis of lipase and lipoxygenase genes in rice (Oryza sativa var. Pusa Basmati 1) bran during germination

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Kshitija Sinha a , Ranjeet Kaur b , Nishu Singh c , Sumandeep Kaur d , Vikas Rishi a ,

Rupam Kumar Bhunia
a, *

a
National Agri-Food Biotechnology Institute (NABI), Plant Tissue Culture and Genetic Engineering , Mohali , 140306, Punjab , India

b
Department of Genetics, University of Delhi South Campus, New Delhi , 110026, India
c Department of Biotechnology , Banasthali Vidyapith , Vanasthali , 304022, Rajasthan , India

Department of Biotechnology, Sector-25, Panjab University, Chandigarh , 160014, India

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: A B S T R A C T

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
Oil-producing crops have been one of the most dynamic parts of agriculture. Worldwide, over the next thirty years, demand for vegetable oils is expected to double, with increasing requirements for food, feed, and fuel. Storage lipids are the major energy reserve stored in the form of triacylglycerols (TAGs) in oil-seed crops including cereals such as rice, oats, barley, and corn. Most of the cereal plants store carbohydrates and proteins in the endosperm; and TAGs and micronutrients in the bran layer, that is further used for oil extraction (
).

Since the lipases and LOXs have a role in lipid mobilization and FA peroxidation, this research was aimed to comprehend the involvement of different lipases and LOXs in the mobilization of rice bran storage lipids during and after germination. This understanding of lipid mobilization and expression analysis of lipases and LOXs is crucial for the development of future genome editing approach to develop low rancid bran oil.

sec.title: 2.1. Lipid reserve mobilization during germination
2.2. Compositional changes in FA profiles of TAGs, DAGs, NEFAs and
sec.p: PLs during germination

sec.title: 2.3. Identification of rice lipase and LOX genes
sec.p:
Apart from these 11 lipases, we also included sugar-dependent1 ( SDP1 , LOC_Os01g55650) as a candidate lipase for our study, taking the count to 12 lipases. SDP1 was identified as the major lipase involved in TAG reserve mobilization during seedling growth in
Arabidopsis ( Thazar-Poulot et al., 2015 )
. In order to ensure that our study of rice lipases was exhaustive, a phylogenetic tree analysis of the 74 rice lipases was performed with the known
Arabidopsis TAG
lipases ( Fig. 2 ).

Based on the obtained results, the presence of lipase-conserved motif (GXSXG) and minimum expression ( FPKM ) profile of the lipases in any of the three tissues (Table S3), additional nine rice lipase genes were added to the list for further analysis. However, out of these nine selected rice lipases, three genes were found to be common with the previously selected 12 lipases and were removed from the list. This made the total number of candidate lipase genes as 18, and these were then named as OsLip1 to OsLip18 ( Table 1 ).

A similar search for LOX genes was also performed using the RGAP database and 16 LOXs were identified, which were named as OsLOX1 to OsLOX16 ( Table 2 ). Phylogenetic tree analysis of the identified rice LOXs showed them to possess homology with
Arabidopsis LOX
family of proteins ( Fig. 3 ). This led us to categorize them on the basis of a previously accepted classification of LOXs, i.e., 9-LOX and 13-LOX (
;
). OsLOX1-4, 6, 9–10, and 13 were grouped as 9-LOX due to their close similarity with the biochemically-characterized
Arabidopsis
9-LOX family proteins (AtLOX1 and AtLOX5), while OsLOX5, 7–8, 11–12, and 14–16 were grouped as 13-LOX due to their high proximity with
Arabidopsis
13-LOX family proteins (AtLOX2-4 and 6) ( Fig. 3 ).

sec.title: 2.4. Structural analysis of rice lipase and LOX genes
sec.p: To decipher the detailed gene structure of the lipase and LOX genes, we performed the exon-intron analysis ( Fig. 4a and b ) and motif identification ( Fig. 5a and b ). By aligning the coding sequences of the candidate genes with their corresponding genomic DNA sequences using gene structure display server ( GSDS 2.0), we investigated the presence of variable number of exons and introns in each of them ( Fig. 4a and b ). Among the lipase genes, OsLip1 , OsLip2 , OsLip9 , and OsLip13 , were shown to possess ten exons and nine introns, while the rest of them have exons and introns ranging between 1-9 and 0–8, respectively. On the other hand, only one LOX gene, i.e., OsLOX4 , contained ten exons and nine introns, while OsLOX1 , OsLOX7 , and OsLOX9 were found to be composed of nine exons and eight introns.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: DAP, Days after pollination; FPKM, fragments per kilo base per million mapped reads.

sec.title: Orphanage
2.5. Transcript profiling of lipase genes during rice grain development and germination
sec.p: In contrast to this observation, OsLip16 displayed relatively high expressions in the developing grains (5 DAP , 13.3 FPKM and 10 DAP , 63.1 FPKM ) and endosperm (152.9 FPKM ), suggesting that the function of this gene might be important to regulate rice grain and endosperm development. In leaves, OsLip3 (279.3 FPKM ) and OsLip4 (66.7 FPKM ) were highly expressed. Despite the high expression levels of OsLip3 and OsLip4 , these genes did not possess any lipase conserved active site motif.

Next, in order to examine the expression pattern of the lipases during rice grain germination, we performed expression analysis of these selected 18 lipase genes by qRT PCR. Changes in gene expression during each germination stages were calculated as normalized log 2 fold changes. One of the major events that determine the growth of the seedling is the lipolysis of storage TAGs by lipases present in seed grains during germination. The genes that were highly expressed after 2 HAI showed a subsequent reduction in their expression levels at the later stages. Amongst the 18 rice bran lipases studied, we found three of them viz., OsLip13 (5.0 fold change), OsLip9 (3.8 fold change), and OsLip1 (3.0 fold change) to be highly expressed during germination ( Fig. 6 ).

Lipase genes those were highly active during grain development showed low levels of transcript expression during germination ( Fig. 6 ). Despite the high expression pattern of OsLip3-4 and
6–7 in
leaves ( Table 1 ), these genes showed relatively low expression in bran of germinating grains ( Fig. 6 ). Although the expression profile of lipases in bran tissue is not available in the RGAP database, the contrasting expression pattern of lipases indicates its involvement in lipid mobilization during grain development and germination.
2.6. Transcript profiling of LOX genes during rice grain development and germination

In order to understand the expression pattern of LOX genes, we mined the publicly available RNA-seq data from RGAP . The analysis revealed that among the 16 selected LOX genes, OsLOX8 (10.0 FPKM ), OsLOX3 (6.8 FPKM ), and OsLOX1 (6.3 FPKM ) were the genes that showed high expression at 5 DAP in rice grain. Interestingly, the expression level of all the genes greatly decreased at 10 DAP ( Table 2 ). In the case of endosperm, OsLOX3 (10.8 FPKM ) and OsLOX2 (5.9 FPKM ) were noted to be the two abundantly expressed genes. OsLOX3 was found to be common and abundantly expressed in developing rice grain and endosperm, suggesting its role during grain development. Similarly, two LOX genes, OsLOX5 (702.7 FPKM ) and OsLOX14 (277.4 FPKM ), were found to be highly expressed in leaf tissues.

To gain further insights into the LOX gene expression profiles in germinating rice grains, qRT PCR analysis was performed for the 16 candidate LOX genes ( Fig. 7 ). The results indicated that most of the examined LOX genes obtained their highest expression peak at the initial stages of germination and then their expression levels decreased as the germination progressed. Upon inspection, we found that OsLOX3 (8.1 fold change) from 9-LOX and OsLOX14 (8.5 fold change) from 13-LOX class showed high expression at 1 DAI and 2 HAI, respectively. As shown in Table 2 and Fig. 7 , OsLOX4 also showed elevated expression in the developing (277.4 FPKM ) and germinating (4.7 fold change) grains, suggesting its diverse role in rice grains.
3. Discussion

The standard practice of bran layer separation disrupts the physical barriers that sequester the cellular lipases and LOXs away from the lipids stored in bran. This, in turn, induces rapid hydrolysis of the bran lipids to high NEFAs. Several efforts have been made to reduce the rancidity and increase the shelf-life of lipids by adapting the pre-milling and postharvesting techniques. However, these techniques have negative impact on the quality of the bran micronutrients (
). Little attention was paid in understanding the causative genes responsible for the hydrolytic and oxidative rancidity of the bran lipids. Thus, it is imperative to target lipase and LOX genes in the grain to improve the quality of bran lipid with lower rancidity and longer shelf-life. The present study was aimed to fill this research gap and to unveil the process of TAG mobilization in rice bran during grain germination along with expression analysis of the lipase and LOX genes.

Our results show that TAGs were the primary lipid reserve stored in rice bran and were mobilized during the post-germinative process (4 HAI-8 DAI). In addition, a thorough examination of the expression pattern of the selected 18 lipases and 16 LOXs revealed that several among them were up-regulated during the period, suggesting these are the key causative genes responsible for the degradation and peroxidation of TAG products.

In order to investigate the expression pattern of the lipases in developing tissues, we mined the RNA-seq transcriptome data. The data obtained showed that the expression profiles of lipase genes differ across the examined tissues. For instance, OsLip3 and OsLip4 exhibited high levels of expression in leaves; OsLip7-8 , 11 , and
16 in
the developing endosperm; OsLip 8 and OsLip 16 in the developing rice grains. To gain further insights into the expression pattern of the bran lipases in germinating rice grains, we performed qRT PCR analysis of the same 18 lipase genes. OsLip1 , OsLip9 , and OsLip13 were found to be highly expressed ( Fig. 6 ), indicating to their involvement in lipid degradation. The results are in agreement with those reported earlier (
). Lipase expression and TAG degradation analysis, demonstrated that the mobilization of the TAG reserve coincides with the lipase expression during the post-germinative growth ( Fig. 1a ).

sec.title: 4. Conclusion
sec.p: Overall, this study identifies the pattern of lipid mobilization and simultaneous expression analysis of lipase and LOX genes in rice bran. Insights were gained regarding the rice bran TAG reserve that remained static during early germination stages but began mobilizing during the post-germinative growth. Furthermore, a total of 18 lipase and 16 LOX genes were identified. In-depth expression analysis during rice grain germination exhibited the lipase and LOX gene expression profiles during the onset of lipid mobilization. High lipase and LOX expression levels in bran tissues revealed the molecular targets for downregulation to accomplish bran shelf-stability. The present work also provides a foundation for future functional studies involving other lipase and LOX genes to decipher their potential impact in oil rancidity.

sec.title: 5.1. Plant material, germination conditions and sampling
sec.p:
Oryza sativa
L. subsp.
Indica var. Pusa Basmati 1
(family: Poaceae ) grains were dehusked manually before germination experiment. Grains were sterilized with 70% ethanol and 0.05% HgCl 2 followed by stratification for 2 days at 4 ◦ C. Seed grains were further imbibed in moistened filter papers by placing in sterile Petri plates to provide the germination condition. The imbibed grains were kept in a growth chamber at 28 ◦ C. Bran tissue was manually dissected from embryo and endosperm at following time intervals: 0 HAI (0 day), 2 HAI (0 day), 1, 2, 4, 6, and 8 DAI of the rice grains. Dissected bran samples were frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at 80 ◦ C before lipid and qRT PCR analyses. Isolated bran fractions were pooled and three sub-pooled replicates were prepared for the analyses.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 5.2. In silico analysis of rice lipase and LOX genes

sec.title: Orphanage
Orphanage
5.3. Lipid analysis
sec.p: Finally, the prepared FAMEs were analyzed in Agilent Technologies Model 7890B gas chromatography-flame ionization detector (GC-FID) with a capillary column (J&W 123–5533, 30 m × 20 μm x 1 μm) and the parameters were set as follows: split less injection, injector, and flame ionization detector temperature at 260 ◦ C, oven temperature program at 110 ◦ C for 5 min, then increasing at 10 ◦ C min 1 to 280 ◦ C and holding this temperature for 15 min. Samples were analyzed in three biological replicates and the individual concentrations of FA components were determined using the known concentration of 17:0 and represented as a μmoles/gram dry weight (μmol/g DW) of bran tissues. Unknown FAs present in bran lipids were identified using Supelco 37 component FAME Mix (Sigma, USA ).

sec.title: 5.4. RNA isolation and complementary DNA (cDNA) synthesis
5.5. Quantitative real time PCR (qRT PCR) analysis
sec.p:
For qRT PCR, a CFX96 Touch Real-Time PCR machine (Bio-rad, California , USA ) was used. Each reaction was set up using 1 μl of 100 ng cDNAs and iTaq universal SYBR green supermix (Bio-rad Inc., USA ) at following parameters: 2 min of initial denaturation at 94 ◦ C followed by 40 cycles of 94 ◦ C for 30 s, 55 ◦ C for 15 s, and 68 ◦ C for 30 s. Lipase ( Table S1 ) and LOX ( Table S2 )-specific qRT PCR primers were designed using NCBI-Primer BLAST tool and synthesized by Eurofins Scientific (Bengaluru, India ). The qRT PCR assays were conducted in three replicates. The specificity of each primer was determined by melting curve analysis and 1.5% agarose gel electrophoresis of the amplified qRT PCR product. Relative gene expression of lipase and LOX genes in germinating bran was measured using the 2 –ΔΔ CT method (
), using the average CT (cycle threshold) values for both reference and target genes. Normalization of each reaction was done using the elongation factor 1-alpha ( EF1A , accession no.: XM_015774317.2) as the reference gene. The qRT PCR analysis of lipase and LOX genes was represented as fold change.
Author contributions statement

RKB conceived and designed the study. KS, NS, SK and RKB did the experimental work. KS, RK and RKB analyzed the results. RKB, RK and VR wrote and edit the final version of the revised manuscript. All authors read and approved the manuscript.

sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this research paper.
